# Draft:Madara Premawardhana

Madara Premawardhana is a Sri Lanka-born computer scientist and a researcher specializing in Digital Twins, Artificial Intelligence, and sustainable energy systems. She is a PhD researcher at the University of Buckingham, focusing on simulation and Machine Learning applications to accelerate the global Net Zero transition.
Early life and education
Madara was educated at Girls' High School, Kandy, before completing professional qualifications in Computer Science through the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT. She earned a Bachelor's degree in Information Technology from the University of Moratuwa in 2020. She later pursued doctoral studies at the University of Buckingham, where her PhD research focuses on the application of Digital Twins and AI in sustainable energy.
Career
Madara began her career as a software engineer at SimCentric Sri Lanka, later advancing to Senior Software Engineer. She also held academic roles, including Graduate Teaching Assistant and Visiting Lecturer at the University of Buckingham, where she taught undergraduate and foundation-level computing courses.
In 2023, she taught Computer Science at Akeley Wood School, and also served as a Project Coordinator in Web Development at YMCA Crewe. Her research and teaching primarily revolve around advanced web technologies, data analysis, and energy system simulations.
She has additionally undertaken micro-internships, including a role as Data Analyst at TCS Biosciences Ltd, where she worked on data automation and analysis projects.
Research
Madara's research lies at the intersection of Digital Twins, artificial intelligence, and sustainable energy systems. Her work emphasizes modeling energy infrastructure to predict performance and optimize efficiency, contributing to the broader goal of achieving Net Zero carbon emissions.
Other activities
As a student, Madara was an active member of AIESEC in Sri Lanka, where she held several leadership positions, including Recruitment Organizing Committee President and Vice President of Marketing and Communications for the AIESEC Expansion Conference. She also served as Secretary of the ICT Society at Girls' High School, Kandy 2012-2013.
In addition to student leadership, she has been engaged in public science communication. Madara has contributed as a speaker at Soapbox Science Milton Keynes, presenting her research on Digital Twins and solar energy modeling to wider audiences, with the aim of making science more accessible and promoting the visibility of women in STEM.
Honors and awards
* Worldwide and Sri Lankan Top Candidate – British Computer Society examinations (2016)
* Merit Award – Young Computer Scientist
* Tomorrow’s Leader Award – MK STEM Awards (now Overt STEM Awards), 2025
